title: Families Struggle with High Energy Bills in America
summary: This article tells the story of Kristy Hallowell, a mom from New York who lost her job and then saw her energy bill jump to $1,800 a month. She couldn't pay, so her gas and electricity were turned off for six months. She, her two kids, and her mom had to use a generator to light and heat their house. Now, her electricity is back on with help from a local group, but she still owes $3,000 and worries about another shut-off. Many other American families are also behind on their bills because energy prices have gone up a lot. The article says that electricity prices rose 6.9% in one year, which is faster than other prices. President Trump says costs are falling, but some experts think his actions might make bills higher. The government is also cutting help for low-income people to pay their bills.

background_read: This article is about American families who are struggling to pay their energy bills because prices have gone up a lot. It focuses on one family's story to show how hard it can be when you lose your job and bills get too high. Energy bills include electricity and gas for homes. When people can't pay, their power might be turned off, which makes life very difficult, especially in winter. The article also talks about what leaders like President Trump are saying and doing about this problem, and how it affects many people across the country.
Article_Structure: WHO: Kristy Hallowell and other American families struggling with high energy bills
WHAT: Energy bills have soared, leading to shut-offs and debt for many households
WHERE: In America, with examples from New York and nationwide
WHY: Because energy prices rose faster than inflation, and help for low-income people is being cut
